description: With early modern vowel shortening, from Middle English grete, griet, from Old English grēot, from Proto-Germanic *greutą.

definitionGroups.group: A collection of hard small materials, such as dirt, ground stone, debris from sandblasting or other such grinding, or swarf from metalworking.

entries.meaning: Sand or a sand–salt mixture spread on wet and, especially, icy roads and footpaths to improve traction.

examples: These cookies seem to have grit from nutshells in them.

entries.meaning: A measure of the relative coarseness of an abrasive material such as sandpaper, the smaller the number the coarser the abrasive.
examples: I need a sheet of 100 grit sandpaper.

entries.meaning: (geology) A hard, coarse-grained siliceous sandstone; gritstone. Also, a finer sharp-grained sandstone, e.g., grindstone grit.
Strength of mind; great courage or fearlessness; fortitude.
examples: That kid with the cast on his arm has the grit to play dodgeball.

verbs.description: grit (third-person singular simple present grits, present participle gritting, simple past and past participle gritted or (nonstandard) grit)

entries.meaning: Apparently only in grit one's teeth: to clench, particularly in reaction to pain or anger.
examples: We had no choice but to grit our teeth and get on with it.
He has a sleeping disorder and grits his teeth.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, intransitive) To give forth a grating sound, like sand under the feet; to grate; to grind.
examples: The sanded |floor that grits beneath the tread.

description: From Middle English *gryt (“bran, chaff”), from Old English grytt, from Proto-West Germanic *gruti (“coarsely ground bits”), ablaut variant of Proto-Indo-European *gʰrewd-. See above. Doublet of goetta.

entries.meaning: (usually in the plural) Husked but unground oats.
(usually in the plural) Coarsely ground corn or hominy used as porridge.
